citation.article-title: Thermodesulfatator atlanticus sp. nov., a thermophilic, chemolithoautotrophic, sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from a Mid-Atlantic Ridge hydrothermal vent
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thermodesulfatator atlanticus sp. nov.
Thermodesulfatator atlanticus (at.lan′ti.cus. L. masc. adj. atlanticus from the Atlantic Ocean, referring to the site of isolation of the type strain).
Cells are Gram-negative motile rods (1.04–6.08 μm long by 0.30–0.75 μm wide) with a single polar flagellum.
Optimal growth occurs at 65–70 °C (range, 55–75 °C), at pH 6.5–7.5 (range, 5.5–8.0) and in the presence of 2.5 % (w/v) NaCl (range, 1.5–4.5 %).
Growth occurs under strictly anaerobic conditions with H2 as an electron donor, sulfate as a terminal electron acceptor and CO2 as a carbon source.
The following are not utilized as electron donors: formate, acetate, lactate, methanol, peptone and yeast extract.
In the presence of H2 and sulfate, monomethylamine, peptone or yeast extract can be used as sole carbon source.
No growth is observed when formate, acetate, propionate, methanol, pyruvate and glucose are provided as sole carbon source.
Does not ferment pyruvate or lactate.
The following are not utilized as electron acceptors: elemental sulfur, l-cystine, thiosulfate, sulfite, nitrate, nitrite and oxygen.
Is able to utilize a wide range of organic and inorganic nitrogen sources.

Resistant to streptomycin and kanamycin (200 μg ml–1), sensitive to ampicillin and penicillin G (10 μg ml–1), sensitive to vancomycin and tetracycline (50 μg ml–1) and sensitive to rifampicin and chloramphenicol (100 μg ml–1).
Predominant fatty acids are C16 : 0, C18 : 1ω7c, C18 : 0 and C19 : 0 cyclo ω8c. The genomic DNA G+C content of the type strain is 45.6 mol%.
The type strain, AT1325T (=DSM 21156T=JCM 15391T), was isolated from the walls of an active deep-sea hydrothermal vent chimney at the Rainbow vent field, on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
It is also available under request at the ‘Souchothèque de Bretagne’ (catalogue LMBE) culture collection (http://www.ifremer.fr/souchotheque/).
